frameDefinitions: A Cognizer construes an Item as belonging to a certain Category.
A Potential_hindrance or an Agent (via their actions) keeps an Event from taking place, or despite the possibility of prevent the Event, do not do so.
The existence of a State_of_affairs is sufficient reason for taking an Action .
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer being aware (or not being aware) of the difference between two Phenomena, which may be expressed jointly or disjointly.
An single Subpart breaks off from a Whole.
An Agent has done or omitted to do an Act or is responsible for the obtaining of a State_of_affairs, which a Judge deems to constitute a violation of an obligation or a moral guideline.
frameExamples: You 've already <t>stereotyped</t> me as a bimbo, have n't you?
Rain <t>prevented</t> the ball game from taking place.
The underwater sequences <t>warrant</t> the price of the admission alone.
It is very difficult for people to visually <t>distinguish</t> between living and non-living things from such a great distance .
The original sword may have <t>chipped</t> off of the statue long ago.
Kim failed to fully <t>justify</t> his decision.
listRoleDefinitions: This is the person who performs an act of categorization. Typically, this frame element is expressed as an External Argument.
This is the entity which is construed or treated by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> as being an instance of a particular <fen>Category</fen>. Typically, the <fen>Item</fen> is expressed as an Object.

This frame element expresses a general type or class of which the <fen>Item</fen> is considered an instance. Typically, it is expressed in a prepositional phrase headed by <ment>as</ment> or <ment>under</ment>.

This frame element expresses properties of the <fen>Item</fen> which is used as a basis for categorization. <fen>Criteria</fen> are the general dimensions along which <fen>Item</fen>s can potentially differ from one another and hence, fall into different <fen>Category</fen>s. For example, a paint sample can be classified <ment>by color</ment> or <ment>by finish (matte or gloss)</ment>; if they are classified by color, one can be classified <ment>as orange</ment> and another <ment>as red</ment>. The <fen>Criteria</fen> role is typically expressed as a PP headed by <ment>by</ment>, or as a complex PP of the form <ment>on the basis of...</ment>:
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate when a certain Categorization was made.
The <fen>Potential_hindrance</fen> is the force which keeps the <fen>Event</fen> from happening, or does not.
The <fen>Event</fen> is prevented from occurring by the <fen>Preventing_cause</fen> or the <fen>Agent</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the sentient being which keeps the <fen>Event</fen> from happening.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the <fen>Potential_hindrance</fen> or <fen>Agent</fen> keeps the <fen>Event</fen> from taking place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the <fen>Potential_hindrance</fen> or <fen>Agent</fen> keeps the <fen>Event</fen> from taking place.
An Eventuality or an Entity that is taken to constitute sufficient reason for taking another <fen>Action</fen>.
An <fen>Action</fen> that is taken to be justifiable given the <fen>State_of_Affairs</fen>.
The cognizer is the person (or other sentient being) who potentially determines that two Phenomena are distinct from each other. It is normally expressed as an External Argument:

The phenomena that are potentially judged to be different from one another can be expressed as separate constituents. When they are, one is typically expressed as an NP Object, and the other as a PP Complement headed by <ment>from</ment>:
See Phenomenon_1, above. The phenomenon expressed less prominently as a PP complement is called <fen>Phenomenon_2</fen>:
Both phenomena that are potentially judged to be different from one another can be expressed jointly by the same constituent:

This is a property that is potentially used by the Cognizer to distinguish one phenomenon from another. It is normally expressed as a PP headed by a preposition such as <ment>from</ment>, <ment>by</ment>, or <ment>on the basis of</ment>:
The part of the <fen>Whole</fen> that is conceived as being broken or taken off from the remaining part of the whole.
The piece that is presented in a less prominent position, and which is the landmark or remaining whole from which <fen>Sub_part</fen> breaks off.
The time at which the breaking off of the <fen>Sub_part</fen> happens.
The location at which the breaking off occurs.
The person or organization that  is held responsible for a prior <fen>Act</fen> or for a <fen>State_of_affairs</fen>.
An action  for which the <fen>Agent</fen> is held responsible, frequently one that the <fen>Agent</fen> has taken themself.
A <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> that the Agent is held responsible for.
The <fen>Time</fen> of the justifying event.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Kim</fex> categorized the books under fiction. <fex>Kim</fex> categorized them on the basis of genre.
The students were categorized <fex>on the basis of their test scores</fex>.
<fex>20 years ago</fex> people would consider this as nothing unusual
<fex>A heavy contact to the opponent 's face</fex> may not merit just a verbal warning
<fex>The teacher</fex> couldn't distinguish one child from the other.
The teacher couldn't distinguish Pat from Kim.
The teacher couldn't distinguish Pat <fex>from Kim</fex>.
The coach could distinguish the twins <fex>by their hair</fex>.
The handle broke off of the pot.
The handle broke <fex>off of the pot</fex>.
<fex>Smithers</fex> defended his decision by insisting that he had used his best judgment
Kim failed  to fully justify <fex>his decision</fex>.
The lawyers tried  to justify <fex>enormous punitive damages being paid to victims on a first-past-the-post system</fex> .

passageCandidateSpans.text: Anatomy of a Hitchens Hatchet Job"
